nodes.body:
Return from death narratives ('das log) are accounts of people who have died and returned to life. According to a common belief, in the first three days of the death process there is the possibility that a person is not completely dead and might return to life. These narratives then are said to record the experiences of the person while dead. Usually the person goes to hell and meets people who convey messages to bring back to the living. The accounts sometimes even include meeting lamas who engaged in evil activities and have fallen into hell. Works in this genre can also relate methods for helping people who have ended up in hell.

Famous return from death narratives are those by stag bla dkon mchog rgyal mtshan, shar dwags po bkra shis rnam rgyal, and 'das log gling bza' chos skyid. See also Bryan J. Cuevas, Travels in the Netherworld: Buddhist Popular Narratives of Death and the Afterlife in Tibet (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2008).
